resourceDesc: Visit the IT Services website to learn more about the University’s digital spaces, services and technologies, including: connecting to WiFi/VPN/Halls of residence internet support, activating your IT account, accessing email, finding a PC on campus or remotely, printing, Microsoft Office 365 and more

Contact the Library Digital Support Services Team for support with accessing the University’s digital services, such as email or My Manchester, on your own device, and browse the full range of Library IT support services.

Assistive software such as Mindview and TextHelp Read and Write 10 is available on all University PC’s. This software is designed for neurodivergent learners, such as dyslexic students or those with visual impairments but is often helpful to all learners. Find out more about assistive software on the Disability Advisory and Support Service (DASS) website.

Access the Library’s My Learning Essentials programme which includes workshops and online resources to support you in developing key information skills such as searching effectively and critical analysis, communicating effectively through different media such as presentations or reports and managing and manipulating data.

Specialist Library Support provides expert support to students, staff and researchers wishing to increase their proficiency using specialist tools like reference management software to organise information or learn high-level media and data literacies such as copyright compliance and interrogating business data.
The University’s Research IT Team can support researchers and staff to select the best software and technology to support them with tasks such as data engineering and storing sensitive research data.

This free two-week online course from the University of Leeds, available from Future Learn, will help you to effectively manage your online identity as you participate in online learning activities and communicate with your peers in the digital sphere: Learning Online: Managing your online identity.

Start to finish: Group work is a collection of online resources from My Learning Essentials which will support you in understanding how digital communication and collaboration can help you achieve greater success in group work and projects.

When communicating and collaborating with others online, it is important to take steps to protect your safety. You can find practical advice about how to secure your personal data and devices from the Get Safe Online website.

Check out the library’s Researcher Services website or contact the Research Service Team for support and advice in how to navigate the publishing process and maximise your research profile as well as the impact and reach of your publications.
Check out Code Club from the Library, a supportive club for all coding enthusiasts - from complete beginners to those working on their own existing projects.

resourceTitle: Introduction to video editing with VideoPad
resourceDesc: Work through this guide: An Introduction to video editing with VideoPad video editor by the University’s Media Services team and get started with engaging and sharing creatively online.

The Library’s free online course Essential skills for online learning, available via the Open Learn platform is an excellent introduction to skills and strategies which will help you get the most of being an online learner.
Learning Strategies for effective note making can support you in learning online and participating successfully in online activities.

resourceTitle: Writing support from My Learning Essentials
resourceDesc: This collection of resources from My Learning Essentials can support you with approaching academic writing using a range of effective tools and strategies.
Read this useful blogpost from My Learning Essentials about Looking after your digital wellbeing.

The University of Manchester Counselling Service website offers access to a fantastic range of applications, online resources and communities which you can use to proactively support your wellbeing in the digital sphere.
Learn to stay safe online with this guidance from IT Services.

If you would like some support thinking about preparing for jobs, or exploring different careers, explore the resources on the University’s Careers Service website or get in touch with one of their advisors.
Create your professional profile and connect with others on LinkedIn with this guide from the University’s Careers Service.

resourceTitle: Make the most of digital capabilities on your CV
resourceDesc: This blogpost from the University Careers Service gives examples of how you can evidence your digital capabilities when updating your CV: Digital CV makeover? You are savvier than you think.
